items.message: Flooding is possible throughout the day on Thursday.  Heavy rainfall during Wednesday evening and into Thursday has caused rivers to rise.  Further heavy rain associated with Storm Ciaran is forecast through Thursday morning, with 20-30mm expected between 6am and noon, accompanied by strong gale force winds. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers is possible.  The main area of concern is the River Allen.  We expect rivers to remain high throughout Thursday and further Flood Warnings may be required.  Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast at Mounts Bay, seafront properties
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Peak spring tides from the weekend have passed, however the risk of coastal flooding increases again from Wednesday.

Storm Ciaran is set to bring strong winds, significant waves and a tidal surge leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding. Key tides of concern are on Wednesday evening, 1st Nov at 18:42 and Thursday morning, 2nd Nov at 07:00. The times given are for Newlyn and will vary along the coast.  

Possibly significant wind and wave overtopping could result in dangerous conditions on the coastline with the potential for fast flowing water. Take care near the coastline and do not drive through waves or flood water.  Please continue to monitor your local weather conditions and take care in the areas of concern. 

We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates.

items.message:
Flooding is possible from late Wednesday evening 1st November, and into Thursday morning. 

Heavy rain falling in Devon due to Storm Ciaran has caused the River Exe to start rising. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to local rivers from around 10:30pm on Wednesday evening is possible. 

Flood Warnings may be required. Please take care near the areas of concern. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated on Thursday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We expect river levels to remain high on spring tides until at least 03/11/23. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 02/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Dauntsey Brook at Dauntsey, Old Sodom Lane and The Green areas
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Dauntsey Brook due to rainfall.
This Flood Warning has been issued because flooding is expected this morning on 02/11/2023.
Further rain throughout the day is expected to cause the river level to rise.
Areas most at risk include riverside properties on Old Sodom Lane, The Green and Dauntsey Green including Earl Danbys Primary School. Sodom Lane and the area around the Providance Chapel. .
River levels are expected to remain high this afternoon and flooding of properties will continue.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 07:00 PM on 02/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Washingborough to Metheringham
items.message: Following Storm Babet and subsequent heavy rainfall, water levels in the Witham Catchment remain high. We are actively monitoring the bank of the river near Fiskerton village, and have installed cameras to monitor the location continuously. We have agreed an action plan with the Local Resilience Forum should circumstances change. We urge residents in Fiskerton village, Short Ferry Caravan Park and properties along Ferry Road area to remain vigilant, and stay up to date with the latest advice. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Axe (Upper) from Winsham to Axminster, including Chard Junction and Weycroft
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Heavy rain falling in the area will continue to fall throughout the night and into morning causing the River Axe to rise.
Flooding to Riverside property and highways including A358 crossing at Weycroft and other Minor roads near to and across the river is expected.  
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Rame Head to Wembury Bay including tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Peak spring tides from the weekend have passed, however, the risk of coastal flooding increases again from Wednesday.

Storm Ciaran is set to bring strong winds, significant waves and a tidal surge leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding. Key tides of concern are on Wednesday evening, 1st Nov at 19:51 and Thursday morning, 2nd Nov at 08:02. The times given are for Plymouth and will vary along the coast. 
 
Possibly significant wind and wave overtopping could result in dangerous conditions on the coastline with the potential for fast flowing water. Take care near the coastline and do not drive through waves or flood water.  Please continue to monitor your local weather conditions and take care in the areas of concern.
  
Notter Bridge, Embankment Rd Plymouth, Torpoint Ferry Terminals & Noss Mayo are particularly at risk.

items.message: Flooding is possible throughout the day on Thursday. Heavy rainfall during Wednesday evening and into Thursday has caused the River Plym and Tory Brook to rise. Further heavy rain associated with Storm Ciaran is forecast through Thursday morning, with 20-30mm expected between 6am and noon. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river is possible. We expect the river to remain high throughout Thursday, and further Flood Warnings may be required.  Take care and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Thursday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected this morning, Thursday 2nd November. 

Heavy rain has fallen overnight and is continuing throughout Thursday morning, accompanied by strong winds associated with Storm Ciaran. This is causing the River Strat and River Neet to rise and the river is likely to remain high through the day. 

Properties and low lying areas in Helebridge will start to flood first from around 10:30 on Thursday. River levels will be at their high throughout today. 

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. 

We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.
